channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Inmate dies at Chuckawalla Valley, site of worst coronavirus outbreak in prison system
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: While the prisoner's cause of death has not been confirmed, it appears the man died of complications related to COVID-19, the first coronavirus-related death at the prison.
item.content:encoded: While the prisoner's cause of death has not been confirmed, it appears the man died of complications related to COVID-19, the first coronavirus-related death at the prison.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California is on the cusp of 5,000 COVID-19 deaths as more businesses reopen
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Colleen Shalby, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Both the state and Los Angeles County recorded their largest one-day increases in new COVID-19 cases Thursday.
item.content:encoded: Both the state and Los Angeles County recorded their largest one-day increases in new COVID-19 cases Thursday.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA - JUNE 11: Mall employee Glenby Ramirez, right, wipes down the escalator handrail while shopper pass by as South Coast Plaza reopens, requiring customers maintain a social distance and wear face masks at South Coast Plaza Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Costa Mesa, CA. Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Some shun wearing masks even though they're essential coronavirus protection
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sandhya Kambhampati
item.description: In California, mandatory face coverings that experts say reduce the spread of the coronavirus are at the center of an intense political fight.
item.content:encoded: In California, mandatory face coverings that experts say reduce the spread of the coronavirus are at the center of an intense political fight.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - JUNE 11: People walk along Harbor boulevard in downtown Fullerton on a warm late Spring day on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. In an abrupt shift in health orders following weeks of debate over the use of face coverings to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, officials in Orange County announced that OC residents no long have to wear masks in public.

item.title: Nonracist to antiracist: Seven rapid culture shifts since the killing of George Floyd
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.description: Prompted by the police killing of George Floyd, American culture has radically transformed in less than three weeks. Here are seven key shifts.
item.content:encoded: Prompted by the police killing of George Floyd, American culture has radically transformed in less than three weeks. Here are seven key shifts.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 05: Katyana DeCampos, a citizen of France visiting California, marched with a sign with the words "Anti Racism," joining nearly 1,000 people gathered to protest the death of George Floyd and in support of Black Lives Matter, in downtown, Los Angeles, CA, on Friday, June 5, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Miss the fish? Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach reopens this weekend
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: An updated coral reef exhibit will debut. Members can return Friday, and all visitors will be welcome Sunday.
item.content:encoded: An updated coral reef exhibit will debut. Members can return Friday, and all visitors will be welcome Sunday.

media:content.media:description: A seahorse is on display at the Aquarium of the Pacific.

item.title: California lawmakers bristle at Newsom's use of executive power during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: California lawmakers are frustrated with Gov. Gavin Newsom's use of power during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers are frustrated with Gov. Gavin Newsom's use of power during the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Wearing a face mask reading "California safe," Assemblyman Kevin Kiley, right, R-Granite Bay, attends a hearing of the Assembly Transportation Committee in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, May 4, 2020. Assembly members returned to the Capitol on Monday after a nearly six-week layoff due to the coronavirus pandemic. Committee members wore masks, and practiced social distancing by meeting in the Assembly chamber, instead of a smaller hearing room. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: London Breed pushes San Francisco reforms: police no longer will respond to noncriminal calls
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco officers will stop responding to disputes between neighbors, reports about homeless people and school discipline interventions.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco officers will stop responding to disputes between neighbors, reports about homeless people and school discipline interventions.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken June 1, 2020, San Francisco Mayor London Breed speaks to a group protesting police racism outside City Hall in San Francisco. San Francisco police will stop responding to neighbor disputes, reports on homeless people, school discipline interventions and other non-criminal activities as part of a police reform plan announced Thursday, June 11, 2020. Mayor London Breed's said officers would be replaced on non-violent calls by trained and non-armed professionals to limit unnecessary confrontation between the police department and the community. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Family questions fatal shooting of Lancaster man by Sheriff's deputy
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Luke Money
item.description: Deputies tried to detain the man, but he refused to comply with their orders and tried to grab a deputy's firearm, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Deputies tried to detain the man, but he refused to comply with their orders and tried to grab a deputy's firearm, authorities said.

item.title: Racism is the reason Black people are disproportionately homeless in L.A., report shows
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: Black people make up 8% of L.A., but more than a third of its homeless population, according to the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority's homeless count report released Friday.
item.content:encoded: Black people make up 8% of L.A., but more than a third of its homeless population, according to the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority's homeless count report released Friday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 04: A protestors hands Isaac D., right, homeless, a bottle of water as he watches protestors march in solidarity against last week's death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, in the 2nd Street Tunnel on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Homeless are exempt from the curfew in place for the protesters. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Community college presidents aim to address 'tremendous racial inequities' on campuses
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: The newly formed alliance will train college representatives on topics like hiring and retaining faculty of color, fostering inclusive classrooms and integrating race across the curriculum.
item.content:encoded: The newly formed alliance will train college representatives on topics like hiring and retaining faculty of color, fostering inclusive classrooms and integrating race across the curriculum.

media:content.media:description: Students walk between classes at Los Angeles City College on Sept. 28, 2016.

item.title: Police say projectile launchers are safer than other 'less lethal' alternatives. Injured protesters disagree
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: Police in Los Angeles and other cities have fired 40-millimeter foam bullets at George Floyd protesters, drawing complaints of excessive force.
item.content:encoded: Police in Los Angeles and other cities have fired 40-millimeter foam bullets at George Floyd protesters, drawing complaints of excessive force.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 30, 2020-A protestor is taken into custody at 3rd St. and Fairfax Ave. in Los Angeles Saturday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Wally Skalij/Wally Skalij/Wally Skalij/Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times

item.title: A revolt against wearing masks creates a new coronavirus danger as California reopens
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Stephanie Lai, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Some residents are revolting against rules forcing them to wear masks in public, creating new coronavirus dangers
item.content:encoded: Some residents are revolting against rules forcing them to wear masks in public, creating new coronavirus dangers

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - JUNE 11: People walk along Harbor boulevard in downtown Fullerton on a warm late Spring day on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. In an abrupt shift in health orders following weeks of debate over the use of face coverings to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, officials in Orange County announced that OC residents no long have to wear masks in public.

item.title: Nearly 160 coronavirus vaccines are in the works. Here's a closer look at the science
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The global race for a coronavirus vaccine involves a few basic approaches. Some have been around for decades, others are being tried for the first time.
item.content:encoded: The global race for a coronavirus vaccine involves a few basic approaches. Some have been around for decades, others are being tried for the first time.

media:content.media:description: Vials used to prepare syringes in a safety study of a potential coronavirus vaccine developed by the National Institutes of Health and Moderna Inc.

item.title: Homelessness jumped 13% in L.A. County, 14% in the city before pandemic
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Doug Smith
item.description: Despite hundreds of millions of dollars spent to curb homelessness, the number of people without a home in Los Angeles grew for the fifth time in the past six years, officials announced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Despite hundreds of millions of dollars spent to curb homelessness, the number of people without a home in Los Angeles grew for the fifth time in the past six years, officials announced Friday.

media:content.media:description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, CA - JANUARY 21, 2020 - Gospel musician Clemmie Williams, 34, lives homeless in North Hollywood Park on January 21, 2020. Williams has been working on part time jobs but it's not enough to make first and last for an apartment he says. "It's a struggle to get back to normalcy," Williams said. Williams was photographed on the first night of the 2020 LA County homeless count. On Tuesday, volunteers with the focused on the San Gabriel and San Fernando valleys. Other swaths of the region, such as the South Bay and Antelope Valley, will be covered Wednesday and Thursday.. The homeless count is overseen by the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) The volunteers will canvas more than 80 cities and 200 communities across L.A. County over three days to count the number of homeless people living on the streets, according to the LAHSA. Last year's count found that nearly 59,000 people were experiencing homelessness countywide, an increase of 12% from 2018. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Anti-Asian tirades appear to be from the same woman
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa, Hannah Fry
item.description: A woman who gained notoriety making racist, anti-Asian comments on Wednesday used bigoted slurs to an Asian man on Thursday.
item.content:encoded: A woman who gained notoriety making racist, anti-Asian comments on Wednesday used bigoted slurs to an Asian man on Thursday.

item.title: Black attorney accuses ACLU of 'flagrantly racist policies' in discrimination lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Sarah O. Clifton contends she was labeled as "angry" or "aggressive" for raising racial equity issues while working as an attorney for the ACLU, according to a lawsuit filed this week.
item.content:encoded: Sarah O. Clifton contends she was labeled as "angry" or "aggressive" for raising racial equity issues while working as an attorney for the ACLU, according to a lawsuit filed this week.

media:content.media:description: ACLU observers watch demonstrators protest near police, Friday, June 5, 2020, in Atlanta. Protests continued following the death of George Floyd, who died after being restrained by Minneapolis police officers on May 25. (AP Photo/Mike Stewart)

item.title: Chinese military officer and researcher arrested at LAX is charged with visa fraud
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Chinese military officer Xin Wang falsified his visa application, attorney David L. Anderson and FBI Special Agent John F. Bennett claim in a criminal complaint.
item.content:encoded: Chinese military officer Xin Wang falsified his visa application, attorney David L. Anderson and FBI Special Agent John F. Bennett claim in a criminal complaint.

item.content:encoded: Drought rapidly developed and intensified in the West after the fifth warmest May on record

item.title: Danny Roman, Mexican Mafia member and South L.A. gang chieftain, is stabbed to death in Corcoran
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Danny Roman, a Mexican Mafia member who controlled swaths of South Los Angeles from various prison cells throughout California, was stabbed to death Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Danny Roman, a Mexican Mafia member who controlled swaths of South Los Angeles from various prison cells throughout California, was stabbed to death Wednesday.

item.title: Police detain Black man who was dancing in the street in Alameda
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The city manager said the incident would be investigated. "I do not know the reasons why the initial officers approached the call the way they did," he said.
item.content:encoded: The city manager said the incident would be investigated. "I do not know the reasons why the initial officers approached the call the way they did," he said.

item.title: Few if any residents of remote Bolinas have been infected with coronavirus, study finds
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Residents of Marin County hamlet may have no COVID-19 antibodies.
item.content:encoded: Residents of Marin County hamlet may have no COVID-19 antibodies.

media:content.media:description: A lone beach goer walks near the waves in Bolinas on Monday, April 27, 2020.

item.title: Mask-wearing shoppers greeted with long lines at newly reopened South Coast Plaza
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: The Costa Mesa shopping mecca opened its doors at 11 a.m. after a three-month closure amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The Costa Mesa shopping mecca opened its doors at 11 a.m. after a three-month closure amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA - MARCH 04: Due to social distancing, shoppers wait in line outside Dolce & Gabbana as South Coast Plaza reopens, requiring customers maintain a social distance and wear face masks at South Coast Plaza Monday, March 4, 2013 in Costa Mesa, CA. Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Goldenvoice announces Coachella festival dates for 2021
item.dc:creator: Randall Roberts
item.description: Promoter Goldenvoice announced April 2021 dates for the Coachella and Stagecoach festivals, which were canceled by Riverside Country officials on Wednesday
item.content:encoded: Promoter Goldenvoice announced April 2021 dates for the Coachella and Stagecoach festivals, which were canceled by Riverside Country officials on Wednesday

media:content.media:description: Set times for the 2015 Coachella festival have been announced. Pictured: A scene from last year's event.

item.title: L.A. faces critical coronavirus test: Will reopening more businesses bring serious new outbreaks?
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Among the rules for newly reopened facilities are a limit on capacity, stringent cleaning requirements and a mandate that staff wear face coverings at all times.
item.content:encoded: Among the rules for newly reopened facilities are a limit on capacity, stringent cleaning requirements and a mandate that staff wear face coverings at all times.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE-CA-APRIL 2, 2020: Robert Hennie, 51, an independent filmmaker, sets up a makeshift gym in the children's playground, where caution tape prevents kids from playing, to slow the spread of the coronavirus, at De Portola Park in Torrance on Thursday, April 2, 2020. Californians are finding ways to work out due to gym closures amid the Coronavirus. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: USC removes name of Rufus von KleinSmid, a eugenics leader, from prominent building
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Tomás Mier
item.description: USC has removed the name of former President Rufus von KleinSmid, a eugenics supporter, from a prominent campus building.
item.content:encoded: USC has removed the name of former President Rufus von KleinSmid, a eugenics supporter, from a prominent campus building.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 11: Rufus B. von KleinSmid's name removed from the University of Southern California International relations building on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. von KleinSmid was the fifth president of the University of Southern California. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Immigration officials bought dirt bikes and boats instead of food and medicine, report says
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Customs and Border Protection officials spent emergency funds meant for immigrant care on dirt bikes, dog food and boats.
item.content:encoded: Customs and Border Protection officials spent emergency funds meant for immigrant care on dirt bikes, dog food and boats.

media:content.media:description: MATAMOROS, MEXICO-MAY 15, 2020-Three-year-old Angie Garcia, originally from El Salvador, washes her hands in a bucket before eating lunch. Her family are asylum seekers living in a refugee camp in Matamoros, Mexico. Hundreds of asylum seekers are waiting under the "Remain in Mexico" program in the camp, where there has yet to be one case of Covid-19 during the pandemic. Sanitation conditions have greatly improved in the camp in the past six months. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man fed homeless people food laced with chemical stronger than pepper spray, prosecutors say
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: A 38-year-old man is facing multiple felony charges after authorities allege he poisoned eight homeless people in a series of videotaped attacks last month in Orange County.
item.content:encoded: A 38-year-old man is facing multiple felony charges after authorities allege he poisoned eight homeless people in a series of videotaped attacks last month in Orange County.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- MONDAY, MAY 11, 2020: Some beach-goers actively use the beach while others relax on the beach, despite Gov. Newsom's active-use-only allowance at the beach in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 11, 2020. The city of Huntington Beach is still pursuing their lawsuit against the state to reopen the beach to all forms of activities - including sun bathing.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Graveyard shooting is California town's first homicide in nearly 25 years
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The tiny town of Colma, Calif., where most of the land is taken up by cemeteries, reports its first homicide in nearly 25 years — in a graveyard.
item.content:encoded: The tiny town of Colma, Calif., where most of the land is taken up by cemeteries, reports its first homicide in nearly 25 years — in a graveyard.

media:content.media:description: Estate planning shouldn't be a do-it-yourself project if your holdings are large enough to trigger taxes. Above, Holy Cross Cemetery in Colma, Calif.

item.title: LAPD officer shown in video striking homeless man defends actions, pleads not guilty
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: LAPD Officer Frank Hernandez pleads not guilty to assault and defends his actions in a viral video that has sparked allegations of police brutality.
item.content:encoded: LAPD Officer Frank Hernandez pleads not guilty to assault and defends his actions in a viral video that has sparked allegations of police brutality.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 11: LAPD Officer Frank Hernandez at arraignment pleaded not guilty to assault charges Thursday after a video showed him repeatedly punching an unarmed homeless man during in Boyle Heights earlier this year. He is due back in court in July. Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: The region's largest landlord group says that the city of Los Angeles' eviction moratorium is unconstitutional.

media:content.media:description: Racial slurs and harassment by another tenant can amount to discrimination under fair-housing laws.

item.title: Arrest records of protesters who weren't charged should be destroyed, lawyers say

item.description: Protesters arrested for curfew violations in Los Angeles aren't being charged, so their records should be sealed and destroyed, their lawyers say.
item.content:encoded: Protesters arrested for curfew violations in Los Angeles aren't being charged, so their records should be sealed and destroyed, their lawyers say.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: Arrests made for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus transmissions keep rising in L.A. County, bringing new dangers for hospitals
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: There is a chance that the nation's most populous county could run out of intensive care unit beds in two to four weeks, officials said Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: There is a chance that the nation's most populous county could run out of intensive care unit beds in two to four weeks, officials said Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 10: A man peddles along the Venice Beach Boardwalk on Wednesday, June 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Hot weather is in the Southland today with a heat advisory in effect until 7 p.m.. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Human remains recovered at Mt. Baldy three months after hiker went missing
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: In late March, a 72-year-old L.A. County man left home for a hike on Mt. Baldy and never returned. Human remains were found over the weekend.
item.content:encoded: In late March, a 72-year-old L.A. County man left home for a hike on Mt. Baldy and never returned. Human remains were found over the weekend.

media:content.media:description: In this file photo, a view of snow–covered Mt. Baldy. On Saturday, a 47-year-old man slipped and fell from a trail on the mountain and later died.

item.title: Lime fire burns 450 acres in Ventura County hills as firefighters try to gain the upper hand
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The brush fire in the hills around Lake Piru is 20% contained, while the Elizabeth fire between Ventura and Santa Paula is 70% contained.
item.content:encoded: The brush fire in the hills around Lake Piru is 20% contained, while the Elizabeth fire between Ventura and Santa Paula is 70% contained.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters battle the 200-acre Lime Fire near Lake Piru in Ventura County on June 10, 2020. (Ventura County Fire Dept.)

item.content:encoded: Mason James Lira is suspected of fatally shooting a Paso Robles man and wounding a sheriff's deputy early Wednesday, authorities said.

item.title: 'They will try to divide us': Protesters demand real accountability for police, prosecutors
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Hundreds of protestors gathered Wednesday decry the practices of police and politicians like Los Angeles District Attorney Jackie Lacey and President Trump.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of protestors gathered Wednesday decry the practices of police and politicians like Los Angeles District Attorney Jackie Lacey and President Trump.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - JUNE 10, 2020. A shell casing serves as a vase for flowers on the sidewalk outside the L.A. County Hall of Justice in downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Hundreds of Black Lives Matter Los Angeles members and their supporters called for an end to the tenure of Los Angeles District Attorney Jackie Lacey over her alleged failure to prosecute officer-involved killings. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'We do not want you here': Racist tirade against woman in Torrance park goes viral
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: 'We do not want you here': Video of woman's racist tirade against another woman exercising at Torrance park goes viral.
item.content:encoded: 'We do not want you here': Video of woman's racist tirade against another woman exercising at Torrance park goes viral.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA-JUNE 12, 2020: Shannan Tarver, 35, left, of Marina del Rey, talks with Sherry, 38 of Torrance,(she didn't want her last name used), after giving her an orchid, at the conclusion of a rally and workout titled, "We Sweat With You," at Charles H. Wilson Park in Torrance, where a woman made racist, anti-Asian comments to Sherry, as she was exercising in the park, earlier this week. The same woman made anti-asian comments to an Asian male in the driver's seat of his car parked next to hers. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Coronavirus batters finances of Black healthcare centers in the Bay Area

item.description: Several Bay Area health clinics provide crucial services to African Americans and other neglected populations. But the pandemic has hurt their finances and those of other clinics nationwide.
item.content:encoded: Several Bay Area health clinics provide crucial services to African Americans and other neglected populations. But the pandemic has hurt their finances and those of other clinics nationwide.

media:content.media:description: Local men routinely gather to socialize in the parking lot of Marin City's public housing "low rises." Longtime residents like Kurth Bailey (center) and Andrew Johnson (right) were among the first settlers of Marin City, whose families moved here from the South in the 1940s and '50s. (Rachel Scheier for KHN)

item.title: A coronavirus vaccine in 2020? Maybe. Here's what has to go right
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: Can a coronavirus vaccine really be developed this year? Dr. Anthony Fauci and other experts say it's possible but far from certain.
item.content:encoded: Can a coronavirus vaccine really be developed this year? Dr. Anthony Fauci and other experts say it's possible but far from certain.

media:content.media:description: A clinical trial participant in England is injected with either an experimental COVID-19 vaccine or a placebo shot. Trials like this are underway around the world.

item.title: LAPD's use of batons, other weapons appears to violate rules, significantly injuring protesters, Times review finds
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Soumya Karlamangla, Richard Winton
item.description: LAPD used violence to quell protests over police brutality, using batons and 'less lethal' bullets in ways that probably violated protocols.
item.content:encoded: LAPD used violence to quell protests over police brutality, using batons and 'less lethal' bullets in ways that probably violated protocols.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 01: People are being arrested for curfew violation in the Hollywood neighborhood on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Earlier in the day their werwe peaceful protests against police brutality and racial discrimination in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. The National Guard has been called to Los Angeles. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UC chief Janet Napolitano leaving office with a mended legacy
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Janet Napolitano took the helm of the University of California seven years ago and initially stumbled. But she leaves UC with advances on many causes.
item.content:encoded: Janet Napolitano took the helm of the University of California seven years ago and initially stumbled. But she leaves UC with advances on many causes.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CA - MARCH 13, 2019 ? UC President Janet Napolitano speaks on the issue of the college bribery scandal during the Regents meeting at UCLA in Westwood on March 13, 2019. Napolitano said they need to look at the admissions process at UC universities. A UCLA men's soccer coach was put on leave for being involved in the bribery scandal. Only two students mentioned the scandal during the open session of the meeting. Most students at the meeting were there to protest tuition increase and fair pay for workers throughout the UC campuses. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As millions protest systemic racism, Californians could soon have chance to restore affirmative action
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: The Legislature may have placed the proposed state constitutional amendment on the ballot anyway. But when a white Minneapolis cop crushed the life out of a handcuffed Black man by kneeling on his neck, the measure became practically unstoppable in the state Capitol.
item.content:encoded: The Legislature may have placed the proposed state constitutional amendment on the ballot anyway. But when a white Minneapolis cop crushed the life out of a handcuffed Black man by kneeling on his neck, the measure became practically unstoppable in the state Capitol.

media:content.media:description: Assemblywoman Shirley Weber, D-San Diego, chair of the Legislative Black Caucus, answers a question about police use of force, during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, June 2, 2020. The Black Caucus pushed for colleagues to pass bills that include reparations for African Americans and reforming oversight of police use of force incidents. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Twin fires burn Ventura County hills, at least 450 acres in flames
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: A pair of fires, the Lime and Elizabeth fires, have at least 450 acres of hills and woods between Ventura and Santa Paula in flames.
item.content:encoded: A pair of fires, the Lime and Elizabeth fires, have at least 450 acres of hills and woods between Ventura and Santa Paula in flames.

media:content.media:description: A "hotshot" crew heads out to fight the Ventura County fire on the ground after aircraft hit flames along Balcom Canyon Road in Somis.

item.title: Woman fatally shot outside Orange County hotel, likely by man she knew
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: A woman in her 40s was shot to death Wednesday afternoon in the parking lot of the Hilton Garden Inn in Lake Forest.
item.content:encoded: A woman in her 40s was shot to death Wednesday afternoon in the parking lot of the Hilton Garden Inn in Lake Forest.

item.title: L.A. officials want more money for community policing. Activists say it misses the point

item.description: Two members of the Los Angeles City Council are calling for diverting some police funding into expanding community policing.
item.content:encoded: Two members of the Los Angeles City Council are calling for diverting some police funding into expanding community policing.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Council member Joe Buscaino at a City Council meeting in June. Buscaino--Mayor Garcetti's appointee to the South Coast Air Quality Management District--backed an industry-led plan that will more gradually reduce local air pollution than an alternative proposal.

item.title: Plan to restore affirmative action in California clears hurdle after emotional debate
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: The plan would strike from California's Constitution the rules imposed by Proposition 209, which prohibits government agencies and institutions from giving preferential treatment to individuals on the basis of race or sex
item.content:encoded: The plan would strike from California's Constitution the rules imposed by Proposition 209, which prohibits government agencies and institutions from giving preferential treatment to individuals on the basis of race or sex

The Black Caucus pushed for colleagues to pass bills that include reparations for African Americans and reforming oversight of police use of force incidents. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Coachella and Stagecoach music festivals officially canceled for 2020
item.dc:creator: August Brown
item.description: Riverside County health officials announced the cancellation of the two-weekend Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival as well as the Stagecoach country music festival.
item.content:encoded: Riverside County health officials announced the cancellation of the two-weekend Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival as well as the Stagecoach country music festival.

media:content.media:description: Shadows grow long on the second day of weekend two of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, on the Empire Polo grounds in Indio, CA, April 23, 2016. Coachella and a country music festival have together generated $403 million in economic impact.
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Amid police brutality protests, demonstrators target D.A. Jackie Lacey
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega, Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Lacey, who is locked in a runoff for reelection, has come under fire for not prosecuting more police officers for misconduct.
item.content:encoded: Lacey, who is locked in a runoff for reelection, has come under fire for not prosecuting more police officers for misconduct.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey at a press conference at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles on June 29, 2015.

item.title: Compton leaders call for removal of sheriff's deputies after man's beating
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Compton mayor addresses beating of man by sheriff's deputies
item.content:encoded: Compton mayor addresses beating of man by sheriff's deputies

media:content.media:description: COMPTON, CA - JUNE 10, 2020 - - Compton resident Dalvin Price, 24, right, receives a hug of support from Compton City Mayor Aja Brown at a press conference about his allegedly violent arrest by sheriff's deputies in front of the MLK Monument at the Compton Courthouse on June 10, 2020. On May 31 Price said he was walking home after visiting friends and was stopped by deputies. He doesn't know why they stopped him but eventually was arrested for assault with a deadly weapon other than a gun. "My ribs were fractured," Price said about his rough treatment." "I was mostly scared for my life," he said. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Judicial leaders amend coronavirus order on bail, postpone vote on evictions, foreclosures
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: California's judicial leaders have rescinded an emergency coronavirus order that set bail at zero for defendants accused of low-level crimes.
item.content:encoded: California's judicial leaders have rescinded an emergency coronavirus order that set bail at zero for defendants accused of low-level crimes.

media:content.media:description: MAY 3, 2017 SAN FRANCISCO, CA California Supreme Court Chief Justice Tani Cantil-Sakauye speaks in her downtown San Francisco offices at the courthouse. She has urged federal officials not use state courthouses to enforce immigration laws, . Photo by David Butow/for the Times

item.title: Disneyland is reopening in July. What about other parks?
item.dc:creator: L.A. Times Staff
item.description: How long will it be until Disneyland and other parks reopen? What will they look like? Here's what we know so far.
item.content:encoded: Now that the Happiest Place on Earth has announced plans to reopen July 17, what's the status of other amusement parks? What will they look like upon reopening? Here's what we know so far about some major theme parks in the coronavirus era.

media:content.media:description: Visitors to Disneyland during its 60th Anniversary Diamond Jubilee use a selfie stick to take a photo on June 10, 2015.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: LAPD officer violated department policy when he fatally shot a mentally disabled man at Costco
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: A Los Angeles police officer violated department policy when he fatally shot a mentally disabled man and wounded the man's parents while shopping at a Costco, the Police Commission ruled Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles police officer violated department policy when he fatally shot a mentally disabled man and wounded the man's parents while shopping at a Costco, the Police Commission ruled Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: From left to right: Russell French, Paola French and their son, Kenneth French, at Universal Studios. Kenneth, 32, was shot and killed by an off-duty police officer in a Corona Costco on June 14. (Courtesy of family)

item.title: South Coast Plaza to reopen Thursday after 3-month coronavirus closure
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: More than 110 merchants — including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom — are reopening. Customers will be required to wear face coverings and maintain social distancing.
item.content:encoded: More than 110 merchants — including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom — are reopening. Customers will be required to wear face coverings and maintain social distancing.

media:content.media:description: After visiting Noguchi, we did a drive-by of South Coast Plaza to pay a visit to Welton Becket's Bullock's wing (now a Macy's), completed in the 1970s -- a veritable temple to shopping. Becket is perhaps best known for his iconic Capitol Records building in Hollywood.
media:content.media:credit: Carolina A. Miranda / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Gyms, museums, hotels, day camps, arena sports can reopen in L.A. County on Friday
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: L.A. County announced that gyms, pro-league arenas, day camps, museums, galleries, zoos, aquariums, campgrounds, outdoor recreational areas and hotels will be allowed to reopen Friday.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County announced that gyms, pro-league arenas, day camps, museums, galleries, zoos, aquariums, campgrounds, outdoor recreational areas and hotels will be allowed to reopen Friday.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA., February 11, 2020 — The new gym for tenants-only at The Century Plaza Towers in Century City on Tuesday, February 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. For the first time, the Century Plaza Towers in Century City that opened in 1975 are fully occupied. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD investigating 56 allegations of misconduct by officers during protests; 7 taken out of the field

item.content:encoded: LAPD investigating 56 allegations of misconduct by officers during George Floyd protests

item.title: Column: Protests and 'looting' seem to be the only way Black-owned businesses can get help
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: While Trump has pushed the idea that Black people are destroying the Black economy in the name of Black lives, Oakland is supporting Black businesses.
item.content:encoded: While Trump has pushed the idea that Black people are destroying the Black economy in the name of Black lives, Oakland is supporting Black businesses.

media:content.media:description: The name George Floyd is shown written on a boarded up window to the Fox Theater after protests in Oakland, Calif., Saturday, May 30, 2020. Protests across the country have escalated over the death of George Floyd who died after being restrained by Minneapolis police officers on Memorial Day, May 25.(AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.title: Officials say no turning back on reopening even as coronavirus cases rise
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The bulk of California's cases are still in Los Angeles County, where officials reported 61 additional COVID-19-related deaths and 1,275 new cases on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: The bulk of California's cases are still in Los Angeles County, where officials reported 61 additional COVID-19-related deaths and 1,275 new cases on Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 09, 2020 - - Traffic flows once again into the Dodgers Stadium parking lot for a free drive-up test for COVID-19 in Los Angeles on June 9, 2020. The testing site was closed for a few days during protests over the death of George Floyd. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Police say CHP killed Oakland man who rammed their vehicles; neighbors dispute that version
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Oakland police say CHP officers shot and killed a man and wounded his pregnant girlfriend after he rammed their vehicles.
item.content:encoded: Oakland police say CHP officers shot and killed a man and wounded his pregnant girlfriend after he rammed their vehicles.

media:content.media:description: Friends and neighbors have created a memorial for Eric Salgado near where he was shot and killed by California Highway Patrol officers Saturday night.

item.title: The Huntington Library to reopen most of its gardens starting July 1
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: Museum members can visit starting June 17 and the general public on July 1. Museum galleries are expected to re-open in the fall.
item.content:encoded: Museum members can visit starting June 17 and the general public on July 1. Museum galleries are expected to re-open in the fall.

media:content.media:description: A view of the Huntington's Desert Garden.

item.title: Gunfire at toddler's birthday party kills 2 people and injures 3 others, including a child

item.description: A 10-year-old child was among a group of people shot Tuesday night. Two women were killed in the shooting.
item.content:encoded: A 10-year-old child was among a group of people shot Tuesday night. Two women were killed in the shooting.

item.title: Shooting closes 110 Freeway in Gardena for 6 hours
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: All southbound lanes of the freeway were closed shortly before 4 a.m. and were reopened by 10, the CHP reported.
item.content:encoded: All southbound lanes of the freeway were closed shortly before 4 a.m. and were reopened by 10, the CHP reported.

media:content.media:description: Authorities shut down the southbound lanes of the 110 Freeway in the Gardena area on Wednesday morning following reports of a shooting, according to the California Highway Patrol.

item.title: Body found in Paso Robles during manhunt for deputy's shooter
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: A man was found fatally shot near the Amtrak station. Authorities think it may be related to an attack in which a deputy was shot in the face.
item.content:encoded: A man was found fatally shot near the Amtrak station. Authorities think it may be related to an attack in which a deputy was shot in the face.

media:content.media:description: In this image taken from video and provided by KSBY-TV, an armored vehicle patrols the streets of Paso Robles in California's Central Coast region after a sheriff's deputy was wounded after someone opened fire on a police station early Wednesday, June 10, 2020. The motive was not known. San Luis Obispo County authorities say the shooting began around 3:45 a.m. in Paso Robles and the deputy responded. He was reported to be in serious but stable condition. Gunfire occurred over a span of some minutes but details are unclear. (KSBY-TV via AP)

item.title: These Californians found new sex partners to help ease stress during coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Most forms of in-person social interaction have waned dramatically because of the coronavirus pandemic, and casual sex is no exception. But a minority of people have been willing to assume the risk of one-night trysts in an attempt to ease stress, loneliness and boredom.
item.content:encoded: Most forms of in-person social interaction have waned dramatically because of the coronavirus pandemic, and casual sex is no exception. But a minority of people have been willing to assume the risk of one-night trysts in an attempt to ease stress, loneliness and boredom.

item.title: Across L.A., George Floyd street art sprouts as symbols of injustice and police brutality
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: As protests erupted over the killing of George Floyd, Angelenos honored his life with murals and street art, calling out racial injustice.
item.content:encoded: As protests erupted over the killing of George Floyd, Angelenos honored his life with murals and street art, calling out racial injustice.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 05: Artists have memorialized George Floyd, who died while in-custody of the Minneapolis Police, with murals and street art along Wilmington Ave. and 105th St. in Watts on Friday, June 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: After a nursing home patient died of COVID-19, her daughter fought back
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: "I wake up angry every morning," says the daughter of a woman who lived in a Reseda nursing home with a history of problems.
item.content:encoded: "I wake up angry every morning," says the daughter of a woman who lived in a Reseda nursing home with a history of problems.

media:content.media:description: RESEDA, CA-JUNE 5, 2020: Griselda Nava, 48, photographed at a park, located across the street from Parkwest Healthcare Center in Reseda, holds a photograph of her mother, Florentina Lopez, who died on May 19 from COVID-19 at the age of 66. Lopez was a resident for the past 7 years at Parkwest. A wrongful death lawsuit has been filed against the healthcare center. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Who gets the blame if California sees major new coronavirus outbreaks with reopening?
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Hannah Fry, Luke Money
item.description: Though local officials point to Gov. Gavin Newsom's guidelines as part of the reason they felt it was the right time to reopen their counties, time will tell if the pace is too fast.

item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton, Hannah Fry
item.description: Before the sun rose Wednesday morning, officials said that forward progress of the fire had been stopped. At Camp Pendleton, more than 12 square miles of the base have burned.
item.content:encoded: Before the sun rose Wednesday morning, officials said that forward progress of the fire had been stopped. At Camp Pendleton, more than 12 square miles of the base have burned.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles CA. JUNE 10, 2020 - LAFD Arson investigators Robert Williams, left, and Joe Sanchez investigate the origin of the brush fire that broke out after midnight in the Sepulveda Pass threatening homes of Bel Air Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Firefighters were able to stop forward movement of the blaze at about 50 acres. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

Not aware of the closing of El Chaparral border, they grabbed a taxi to Ped East. | (Alejandro Tamayo, The San Diego Union Tribune 2020)

item.title: All Black Lives Matter march will take place June 14, without L.A. Pride's involvement
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: There will be a Black Lives Matter march in L.A. on June 14. But Christopher Street West, the organization that produces L.A. Pride, will not be involved.
item.content:encoded: There will be a Black Lives Matter march in L.A. on June 14. But Christopher Street West, the organization that produces L.A. Pride, will not be involved.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 08, 2020 - - Participants of a Black Lives Matter-LA memorial service and funeral procession honor George Floyd and demanding justice for those killed by the hands of the police in Los Angeles on June 8, 2020. Interfaith leaders, labor, people of color, immigrants and victims of police brutality attended. The memorial services consisted of four funeral processions beginning in South Los Angeles, Long Beach, Orange County, and the San Fernando Valley. The processions converged in downtown Los Angeles at the crossing of 1st St and Broadway Blvd.. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tribal casinos sue California for more time to qualify legal sports betting measure amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California Native American tribes sued the state Tuesday seeking an extension of the deadline to qualify a sports betting initiative, arguing that the coronavirus lockdown kept them from collecting signatures in public.
item.content:encoded: California Native American tribes sued the state Tuesday seeking an extension of the deadline to qualify a sports betting initiative, arguing that the coronavirus lockdown kept them from collecting signatures in public.

media:content.media:description: Amado Nanalang watches basketball games while making bets at a sports book in Las Vegas.

item.content:encoded: Veteran cop Frank Hernandez was charged with one count of assault under color of authority in connection with the April incident.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey appears at a news conference on June 29, 2015. Lacey sent a letter to county supervisors last week saying that their vote on a jail plan had violated the state's open meetings law.

item.dc:creator: Lorena Iñiguez Elebee
item.description: At one drive-through graduation, the student walked 6 feet behind a classmate, his family in the car, driving slowly and taking video. The ceremony lasted 10 minutes.
item.content:encoded: At one drive-through graduation, the student walked 6 feet behind a classmate, his family in the car, driving slowly and taking video. The ceremony lasted 10 minutes.

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus cases in the state continue to rise steadily as counties further lift stay-at-home restrictions

(Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California DMV to reopen all offices closed because of coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: After reopening some field offices following the state's shutdown due to coronavirus, the California DMV will resume business at all of its locations.
item.content:encoded: After reopening some field offices following the state's shutdown due to coronavirus, the California DMV will resume business at all of its locations.

media:content.media:description: The California Department of Motor Vehicles said that it was alerted to "a potential security issue within its credit card processing services" but that there was no direct evidence its computer system had been breached. Above, a DMV office in Los Angeles in 2012.

item.title: Orange County public health officer resigns in coronavirus controversy
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Luke Money
item.description: Dr. Nichole Quick mandated face coverings in Orange County in May to protect against the coronavirus, drawing ire from residents and elected officials.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Nichole Quick mandated face coverings in Orange County in May to protect against the coronavirus, drawing ire from residents and elected officials.

media:content.media:description: OC Health Care Agency officer Dr. Nichole Quick speaks at a news conference on March 27, 2020. Dr. Quick has quit after receiving threats over an order that residents wear face coverings when near others in public to protect against the coronavirus.(KTLA)

item.title: Racism and inequity fuel coronavirus-related death toll among L.A. County minorities, officials say
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Blacks, Latinos and Pacific Islanders are twice as likely to die as whites in Los Angeles County from the coronavirus, according to new data.
item.content:encoded: Blacks, Latinos and Pacific Islanders are twice as likely to die as whites in Los Angeles County from the coronavirus, according to new data.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-APRIL 15, 2020: A funeral service for Charles Jackson is held at Angelus Funeral Home in Los Angeles for a small group of loved ones on Wednesday, April 15, 2020. Jackson was diagnosed with covid-19 after returning home from a black ski trip in Idaho, and died days later in the hospital. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Barbara restaurant drops name many considered racist
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: 'Sambo' has long been used as a slur against people of color. After a petition, Sambo's, which once had 1,100 franchises, is changing its name.
item.content:encoded: 'Sambo' has long been used as a slur against people of color. After a petition, Sambo's, which once had 1,100 franchises, is changing its name.

media:content.media:description: Rashelle Monet, second from left, led the movement to change the name to "Peace and Love" at Sambo's after a petition spurred the restaurant to change its name.

item.title: Our Lady of Angels Cathedral tolls bells for 8 minutes, 46 seconds to mark George Floyd's funeral
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill, Melissa Gomez, Hannah Fry
item.description: The bells' ringing comes amid another day of protests planned in downtown L.A., Sherman Oaks and West Hollywood, among other locations.
item.content:encoded: The bells' ringing comes amid another day of protests planned in downtown L.A., Sherman Oaks and West Hollywood, among other locations.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 9, 2020: Yulma Luis, 23, Caroline Mendonca, 31, and Steve Pineda, 33, from left, stand quietly in the courtyard of the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels as bells toll for eight minutes and 46 seconds to coincide with the beginning of George Floyd's funeral in Houston, in downtown Los Angeles, California on Tuesday, June, 9, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite coronavirus, these experts support the protests for health reasons

item.description: Large gatherings bring a risk of coronavirus. But health experts are supporting protests being held in response to the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Large gatherings bring a risk of coronavirus. But health experts are supporting protests being held in response to the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Brush fire breaks out near Hollywood Bowl as heat wave continues
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Record high temperature were set in Long Beach and at LAX on Monday, and small fires burned across Southern California.
item.content:encoded: Record high temperature were set in Long Beach and at LAX on Monday, and small fires burned across Southern California.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles CA. JUNE 9, 2020 - Firefighters get a handle on a small vegetation fire that broke out early Tuesday, June 9, 2020, near the Hollywood Bowl. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The coronavirus entered Northern California many times, from many places
item.dc:creator: Melissa Healy
item.description: The coronavirus arrived in Northern California not only from people who brought it in from other states but from international travelers from many places.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus arrived in Northern California not only from people who brought it in from other states but from international travelers from many places.

media:content.media:description: SAN JOSE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 21: (EDITORIAL USE ONLY) A nurse places a blanket over a patient that had just been admitted to the emergency room at Regional Medical Center on May 21, 2020 in San Jose, California. Frontline workers are continuing to care for coronavirus COVID-19 patients throughout the San Francisco Bay Area. Santa Clara county, where this hospital is located, has had the most deaths of any Northern California county, and the earliest known COVID-19 related deaths in the United States. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: 'We can't prevent it': Farmworkers paid low wages fear coronavirus spread in crowded housing
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: Farmworkers have long lived in overcrowded conditions. With the spread of coronavirus, Monterey County is taking action, but vegetable pickers still face a shortage of housing.
item.content:encoded: Farmworkers have long lived in overcrowded conditions. With the spread of coronavirus, Monterey County is taking action, but vegetable pickers still face a shortage of housing.

media:content.media:description: SALINAS, CA -- MAY 21: Odilia Leon, 40, a single mother of five children, a farmworker who picks strawberries, currently makes only $420 a week after her hours were cut due to the coronavirus pandemic, at her home on Thursday, May 21, 2020, in Salinas, CA. Leon is shown with her two sons Omar Ramirez, 4, left, and Esgar Ramirez, 7, in their room. Leon shares a two bedroom one bath house with another family of four. Odilia pays $1050 a month for one room where she sleeps with her five children. She fears for her health and the health of her three children during the coronavirus pandemic. In Monterey County, agriculture workers make up 40% of positive COVID-19 cases and two-thirds of cases are concentrated among Latinos. Farmworkers often live multiple families to a home because of unaffordable housing and low wages. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A perilous balancing act: Reopening L.A. County as coronavirus still stalks communities
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby, Iris Lee
item.description: As the economy reopens, coronavirus cases are beginning to rise
item.content:encoded: As the economy reopens, coronavirus cases are beginning to rise

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 06: Conor Susi, server, center, takes orders from a dine-in group at Faith & Flower in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, June 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As restrictions are lifted and businesses and the economy start to re-open, restaurants are putting in place rules to ensure proper social distancing and the health and safety of guests. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD to halt use of carotid restraints; L.A. County Sheriff's Department pledges to restrict use
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: The Los Angeles Police Department on Monday instructed officers not to use carotid restraints, chokeholds that restrict or block blood flow to the brain, pending a review by the city's Police Commission.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Police Department on Monday instructed officers not to use carotid restraints, chokeholds that restrict or block blood flow to the brain, pending a review by the city's Police Commission.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 30: LAPD Chief of Police Michel Moore speaks with a protester in the Fairfax District on Saturday, May 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Callers to City Hall demand big cuts from the LAPD
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith, David Zahniser
item.description: An L.A. City Council panel heard from members of the public who demanded sharp cuts in the LAPD budget in the wake of George Floyd's death.
item.content:encoded: An L.A. City Council panel heard from members of the public who demanded sharp cuts in the LAPD budget in the wake of George Floyd's death.

media:content.media:description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti said in his State of the City address that he would be shifting 200 officers from elsewhere in the Police Department to its Metropolitan Division, a group that fights crime in different areas of the city. Above, at LAPD headquarters.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Eliminate school police, L.A. teachers union leaders say
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: In the wake of George Floyd's killing, activists are renewing calls to eliminate school police departments as well
item.content:encoded: In the wake of George Floyd's killing, activists are renewing calls to eliminate school police departments as well

media:content.media:description: Sarah Djato, right, listens to speakers during a press conference calling for the removal of police from the Los Angeles school system on Monday, June 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA.

item.title: Nearly 1,000 infected at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison in worst coronavirus outbreak to hit prison system
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: In three weeks, Chuckawalla Valley State Prison has gone from having zero confirmed cases of COVID-19 to 993, the worst coronavirus outbreak to hit the California prison system to date.
item.content:encoded: In three weeks, Chuckawalla Valley State Prison has gone from having zero confirmed cases of COVID-19 to 993, the worst coronavirus outbreak to hit the California prison system to date.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Brush fire in Corona burns 110 acres, but firefighters halt its progress
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A brush fire broke out Monday evening in Corona, burning 110 acres in less than two hours, the Riverside County Fire Department said.
item.content:encoded: A brush fire broke out Monday evening in Corona, burning 110 acres in less than two hours, the Riverside County Fire Department said.

media:content.media:description: A brush fire near Lake Mathews had covered 110 acres by 6 p.m

item.title: California to allow movie theaters to reopen in most counties
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Phil Willon
item.description: California counties that have been allowed to accelerate their reopening of their economy could decide to reopen movie theaters as early as Friday, according to new state guidelines released Monday.
item.content:encoded: California counties that have been allowed to accelerate their reopening of their economy could decide to reopen movie theaters as early as Friday, according to new state guidelines released Monday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 21: The Vista theatre on Sunset Drive in Los Angeles, CA, is closed and left the message, "To Be Continued...," on its marquee, during the coronavirus pandemic, photographed Tuesday, April 21, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Newsom says 150 million N95 masks will arrive after BYD earns federal approval
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Two months after announcing a $1-billion deal with Chinese automaker BYD, Gov. Newsom said Monday that 150 million of the respirators will arrive in California in the coming days to protect workers from the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Two months after announcing a $1-billion deal with Chinese automaker BYD, Gov. Newsom said Monday that 150 million of the respirators will arrive in California in the coming days to protect workers from the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: Ground crew at the Los Angeles International Airport unload pallets of supplies of medical personal protective equipment, PPE, from a China Southern Cargo plane upon arrival on Friday, April 10, 2020. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: Large fire engulfs commercial building in downtown Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A large fire engulfed a commercial building in downtown Los Angeles on Monday afternoon, drawing 112 firefighters to the blaze just east of the city's Fashion District, the Los Angeles Fire Department said.
item.content:encoded: A large fire engulfed a commercial building in downtown Los Angeles on Monday afternoon, drawing 112 firefighters to the blaze just east of the city's Fashion District, the Los Angeles Fire Department said.

item.title: UC clears Regent George Kieffer of allegations of sexual misconduct
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The University of California has cleared Regent George Kieffer of allegations of sexual misconduct, finding insufficient evidence to support a graduate student's claim that he repeatedly squeezed her thigh at a 2014 meeting.
item.content:encoded: The University of California has cleared Regent George Kieffer of allegations of sexual misconduct, finding insufficient evidence to support a graduate student's claim that he repeatedly squeezed her thigh at a 2014 meeting.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 15, 2016: UC President Janet Napolitano,middle, with Regent George Kieffer,left, and Regents chairwoman Monica Lozano, right, listen as UC Riverside gives a presentation during the UC Regents meeting at the Luskin Conference Center on the campus of UCLA on September 15, 2016 in Westwood, California.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California would ban police chokeholds under deal struck by legislative leaders
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: California's Assembly speaker and other key lawmakers on Monday backed making it illegal statewide for police to use a type of neck hold, a response to protests over police brutality.
item.content:encoded: California's Assembly speaker and other key lawmakers on Monday backed making it illegal statewide for police to use a type of neck hold, a response to protests over police brutality.

media:content.media:description: Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon, D-Lakewood, discusses his support to a proposed measure by Assemblyman Mike Gipson, D-Carson, to make it "illegal to use the choke hold and carotid artery restrain tactics to forcibly detain a suspect," during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, June 8, 2020. The proposal appears to go beyond any other state's law and comes after a different restraint hold was used by Minneapolis police was blamed for the death of George Floyd. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Ex-O.C. sheriff's deputies plead guilty in evidence booking scandal
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Several deputies have been charged for failing to properly book evidence seized during criminal investigations, a scandal that could affect thousands of criminal cases.
item.content:encoded: Several deputies have been charged for failing to properly book evidence seized during criminal investigations, a scandal that could affect thousands of criminal cases.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 2019: Orange County Sheriff Don Barnes talks to a reporter at his office in Santa Ana, Calif., on Feb. 19, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
